Description: Body sherd of Clazomenian black-figured pottery slim neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two naked figures dancing (left buttock, leg and right thigh of one dancer to left, and lower back, buttock, genitals, legs and right hand of second dancer to right remaining).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
According to Cook, the Petrie painter is also responsible for British Museum 1888,0208.74, 1888,0208.77a, 1888,0208.78a, and 1888,0208.79a, all of which were found at Tell Defenneh.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 128, no. 12)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 120, no. 339.1, pl. XXXVII)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 231, no. 171)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.108) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4758 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
